author: yorickdowne
content: Just a quickie and not to clutter this Discord: ethstaker faucet works as of yesterday. Does require BrightID verification. The issues with BrightID were resolved and we have users successfully requesting funds from the faucet. It's a couple hoops to jump through, most notably the BrightID Meet Zoom call first, but that only needs to be done once and it's the only way we could protect the faucet from bots

author: robocopsgonemad
content: does anyone have a moment to explain to me why the blocks on mnsf6 are so empty? According to https://explorer.mainnetshadowfork6.ethdevops.io/blocks there are a many empty blocks, and very few that are even half full.  Are we just decaying from mainnet, and running low on valid transactions?

author: parithosh
content: ^ probably just decaying from mainnet. from last few attempts, we get about ~4-5 days of good testing and then it deteriorates fast.

author: funnygiulio
content: For whoever is running a ropsten validator with Erigon, please update to the latest Alpha, a critical bug in block proposing has been patched

author: funnygiulio
content: you may get slashed because of it

author: 0xfornax
content: Big supporter of the merge, but hope you guys can think of a way to fix how we get ether on testnets after they're merged. So far I could just turn on a miner and get as much as needed without needing to explain why. Now that mining on ropsten is almost gone I have to do all kinds of things that the faucet lords tell me, give read access to my twitter, verify on bright id, come back every day to get a 0.1 eth dripped. It is a terrible experience for devs!

author: stevencook
content: maybe the current mining that is getting us to the merge can all go into a decent faucet with at least 50k eth by the time merge happens

author: ajsutton
content: How could the EL get you slashed? (Assuming Erigon isn't a super majority client)

author: funnygiulio
content: is it not a slashing condition?

author: funnygiulio
content: you would broadcast an invalid payload

author: ajsutton
content: You don't get slashed for being wrong - only for being malicious.  Specifically only three things can get you slashed: signing two different blocks for the same slot, signing two different attestations from the same epoch or signing two attestations where the source and target surround each other.

author: yorickdowne
content: The worry appears to be that multiple ELs have the same bug, together comprising a supermajority, but not all do. Muxers would be one way to protect against that.
